comment: I hate to jump on the hype train but this is just SO GOOD!
Thick viscosity. At first similar to a syrup but with a wonderful slightly sweet caramelly finish.

I was very fortunate to find this bottle at a local liquor store on the top shelf for $50.  I don't think they knew what they had and I've been back a couple times and they have nothing interesting beyond a couple of faded bottles of Weller Special Reserve at $60.  Meh.

Update: Some time oxidizing in my liquor cabinet has greatly improved this and I like it a lot more. 

Nose: Amazing.  Explodes with green apple, vanilla, baking spices, especially cinnamon, some oak in the background but mostly sweet and tart apple pie notes.

Flavor: Rich and coating but with a strong alcohol bite up front which I barely got on the nose.  Still delicious apple pie notes with buttery streusel crust.

Finish: A little short but creamy vanilla soda and then a little wood and then nada.  Not complex or long but delicious nonetheless.

I kept going back to the glass for the wonderful nose and the strong flavors but was a little disappointed by the blah finish.  Still a very nice whiskey.
vanilla, stewed fruit and some spice. really nice for the proof

Maple nose with floral undertones. Pallette starts spicy with rising sweet and burn beaking near the finish. Very complex and surprising. Points deducted for being so hard to find. But a 4.5 on its own.
Happy to find this at Sylvain in New Orleans. As others have said, similar to Blantons but spicier.

Bottle pour neat in a Glencairn at Jack Rose Saloon in DC on July 4th.  Nose is very mild, creamy, rich, and moderately sweet, with caramel, vanilla, and peach. Taste is similar; mild but flavorful.  Long finish is mild but tasty.  Big fan.  7/4/19
If you find it, buy it. Enough said.
Recommendation from Matt.  Blantons, but aged longer.
Very good. One of my top 3!

The nose is vanilla and spice.
Very woody at first.  Long, dry finish.  It takes a while for all the flavors to develop- this is a subtle bourbon.  There is a strong sweet rubbing alcohol like flavor from swishing it around my mouth.  Amidst this, there is a grassy and floral flavor - I get strong rose petals that come out over time.  There is a sweetness, maybe apples on the tip of the tongue.  I also get marshmallow.
Expected much more. Smooth but plain. Too mild for me.
Took a little time for the nose to open up, once it did had a nice vanilla and leather smell. Palate of vanilla, caramel, and spice. A very nice long finish of cinnamon.

Friend of mine found and gifted me a bottle of this rich and delicious bourbon. Another friend let me taste his bottle a few months ago. I have tasted around 50 different bourbon/whiskey/rye spirits and so far this is my favorite. It’s unfortunate it is so rare to find. My second favorite is tough but leaning toward High West Bourye. Many more yet to taste!

Very smooth bourbon that doesn't have too much burn to it! This is an amazing bourbon and worth it if you can find it.   

It probably makes very good sense that I like this and I like Blanton's. 
Well done Elmer T Lee RIP.
A solid pour but doesn’t quite live up to the hype for me. RHF is vastly superior at 100 proof.
tasted at hundred north in gilbert. nose sweet, honey. flavor vanilla, spice.

Happened upon a dinner spot that offered pours of ETL, so I had to try one. 1oz pour in a glencairn and let it breathe for 10 minutes. It was fine. Similar to some of the other BT products, my experience is that it didn't live up to the hype. Good citrus and vanilla on the nose, but that's where it ended for me. Taste profile and finish were too spicy and a little earthy. "Just like blantons" was what I was told, but I disagree. I'll drink it again if offered but probably won't buy a bottle.
I have been missing out! Sweet, honey,light. Yummy!

This boy lives up to the hype. Wheat and corn syrup on the nose, first sip was smooth as butter. In fact I got some wheat and biscuit right away along with the corn, then cinnamon hit me hard right in the middle. I looked at the mash bill, and it’s mostly corn with about 15% rye. I’d be surprised if wheat wasn’t in there somewhere. Good bready sweetness, and it lingers.
Vanilla Carmel Berry nose. Spice and burn with slight candied char
Pungent nose of maple, oak, some dark berries in there. Thick mouthfeel, more maple, a little barrel spice coming in. Finish is smooooth.
nice apple cinnamon nose and taste. nice spiciness. also taste hint of cut oats

nose: dark fruits up front like a cherry pie. strong vanilla, some sugar cane, caramel, leather, and a slight hint of butterscotch hit the nose.

delicious! instant vanilla and fruit with some slight honey finish. reminds me a little of the old forester 1910 with some leather taste at the back of the toungue. the finish is nice and long with some burn to it. very good!
Great juice.  On par with the rest of the BT line.  I paid $38 a bottle for this.  The retailers marking it  upwards of $360 should be ashamed of themselves and boycotted.

Elmer T. Lee: yet another elusive Buffalo Trace bourbon that continues to increase in cost and decrease in availability. When I saw this one, I knew I had to pull the trigger. It's a single barrel, sour mash release, making it a little unique to the BT portfolio.

Nose: Spicy but refined. Clove, black pepper, and baking spices. Classic Buffalo Trace leather and cherry jump right out of the glass. There's also vanilla, toffee, Gala apple, cocoa, honey, and caramel. Maybe even a little peach in there. And of course, a very prominent aroma of quality oak. Phenomenal.

Palate: The cherry and leather are still present, but they take a back seat to apple, vanilla, caramel, raisin, and toffee.  Very mild orange citrus. Here and there I pick up a nice slice of apple pie. The spice from the nose is still detectable, but the sweeter notes really take over here. There's even some maple syrup and honey.  Once again, big oak, and it's damn good. While the nose delivers a profile that is distinctly Buffalo Trace, the palate encapsulates what I'd call the classic bourbon character.

Finish: Moderate. Cinnamon, black pepper, and baking spice provide a kick. Once again, the oak shines here.

About as good as it gets on a hot summer day. This is subtle, nuanced, and one of the most drinkable whiskies I've had to date. Dangerously easy. Yet, there's enough going on here to distinguish this one from some of my other favorites from Buffalo Trace.

I nabbed this oen for $70, though I've seen it for about double. $70 is fair; maybe a bit high, but I understand the game BT is playing here. It's still one of the more affordable options in their lineup, even considering inflation. It's so good that I'd gladly overpay, though anything north of a C-note is absurd.

Either way, this is one hell of a dram. For now I'll leave it a 4.75. It's simply amazing. Of course, I'd highly recommend this to any fellow BT fanboy or for anybody who appreciates a subtle, nuanced bourbon. Might add to this post in the future. I've got Col. Taylor SB and Rye, as well as Weller 107. Can't wait to get into some comparisons between these heavy hitters.

Excellent. With one ice cube, appeals to those who favor sweet over spice. Profound caramel and oak nose. Extremely smooth, no burn with the exception of the faintest bite on the very back end. I’m hooked!

Not overly sweet. Nose does not have the cherry of a woodford or angels envy. I get vanilla. Taste: So smooth to start. Slight cherry note but gives way to rose. Really nice. Cherry notes in the aftertaste. A really refined bourbon.
Very spicy but vanilla and floral notes balance it out well.

Another over hyped over priced average bourbon. Don’t get caught up in all the hype. If you find it at retail buy it but most will try to gouge you for it. 
It’s not worth the high secondary price!
Buy Elijah Craig 12 year Barrel proof instead!!!

Nose: vanilla, apple, baking spices, ethanol, caramel, oak
Palate: sweet apple, leather, medium oil, honey, vanilla
Finish: short, strong barrel char, apple cider, cinnamon
Best I have tasted to date. Nose is fruit and faint spice with hint of berries. Color is dark amber. Apple and cinnamon come through with long finish.

Oak, dark fruits like plum and black cherry, pepper, a nice long finish. Actually very Pappy-esque (15 year expression). There’s nothing not to like about this. It’s a winner if you can find it. Price was reasonable- $15 for this pour.

Vanilla and crisp apple on the nose
More Apple , vanilla and baking space on the palate. 
Moderate finish.
Sweet apple pie.. cinnamon finish. So good. Right behind stagg Jr as my favorite.
Upper my star score! So yummy! Mike just moved up a notch.. I guess it is ok we r investing in whiskey!!!
Solid bourbon. Tastes a little hotter than the abv suggests.
oh man, good juice. not sure if it’s because it’s so rare but it is a nice bourbon. little fruity little corny.
Neat: great legs, soft forward stance, openness draws you in, spiced like a bank holiday you can’t wait to enjoy
Smooth, soft finish, but very basic
Sweet caramel with a tight burn. Very flavorful with nice after taste. Strong mouthfeel. Sweet after burn. Does not need to be cut. Quite lovely.
Smooth on the front but very harsh on the back end.  It's a drinkable bourbon but not something to spend time seeking out

Nose: caramel, a full thing of vanilla extract, fruity
Palate: smooth like blanton’s but just a bit tart initially. The tartness takes over the palate buttery/oily with some fruityness coming through
Finish: sour and rich medium finish. 

Honestly very good just not as sweet as blanton’s or Weller. Much more tart
Yummy, smooth and great price point about $38

Neat.  Tons of sweet corn and caramel up front on the nose.  Very similar to Blanton’s on memory with the same honey comb note.  Slight hint of oak and chocolate.

Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Nice honey on the tip of the tongue.  Tons of vanilla sweetness.  Little spice or anything resembling a dark note.  Limited legs.  Just smooth and delicious, with almost zero complexity or interesting characteristics.

Better than any Blanton’s I have had to date, but nothing too special.
Very soft on the palate. Peppery and smooth with a decently long finish for such a cheap bourbon. Really enjoyable and definitely worth the price!
First time I’ve tried this, unbelievable flavor of cinnamon, not strong, great flavor neat!  Also enjoyed with one big ice cube!  Will definitely buy again if I find it!

Nose is very welcoming with a caramel apple from the fair feel.
Very light weight with a nice floral accent to then have a medium spice to add to the end. Great bourbon to share the history and flavors
Initially hot to the taste.  It then becomes a full on flavorful bourbon.  The nose is sweet, vanilla.  Nice hang time in it.
Good, solid bourbon, but it didn’t “wow” me. IMHO it doesn’t live up to the hype, so I certainly won’t be seeking it out and I definitely wouldn’t pay more than $38 retail.
Woody, like oak and some leather, a light tobacco. I was expecting a bigger flavor but it’s surprisingly thin. Very short finish.
I really really want the 100 Anniversary édition that came out. Sad I’ll likely never see one.

Nose: vanilla and pecan pie, spiced cinnamon 
Palate: as described in review, less cinnamon on the finish and  more annatto
Cinnamon and barrel with nice body.  Tasty.
Smooth vanilla. Lighter body than expected. Warming finish

Nose: caramel (not a great nosing glass so couldn’t get much)
Taste: definite rye notes both in terms of spice and a piney botanical note, cola 
Finish: spice warms the tongue but kind of a thin finish
After reading reviews: found the cinnamon on the taste and finish.  Feel like I didn’t give this one a fair shake drinking it at a bar without a glencairn.
My absolute favorite bourbon. Easy drinking at 90 proof with an amazing flavor profile of caramel and maple. Incredibly well done.
Oakey Smokey oily balanced by sweet vanilla and fruit. Nice well rounded bourbon
This is great. Amazing nose, that profile you get from higher end BT products. Good finish too and smooth. Not much to complain about just a great bourbon.

I had been searching for this bottle for a long time and finally got a chance to get it at a lottery at my local shop. I’ve been wanting to compare it to other Buffalo Trace mashbill #2 bottle and now I get to. But here is a review of just this bottle.

The nose is very fruity, bright red apple in particular. There is also baking spices (cinnamon in particular), leather and oak. There’s also a brown sugar, a touch of vanilla and rye.

The palate has a soft, light sweetness and slightly oily texture. I get cooked apple with baking spices, oak, vanilla and a touch of leather.

The finish has some fruit and spices with a nice medium burn. It gets slightly bitter as it fades on this medium-long finish.

I enjoy this one. A little more of a burn than I’m used to for 90 proof, which is not a bad thing.
In my memory, this one seems like the fruitiest of the Buffalo Trace mashbill #2 bunch. I can’t wait to see how it stacks up side-by-side to the others in this mashbill!
A very good reference bourbon. If you can find it buy it.
Spicy Clove, smooth a little dry in the finish, overall more balanced.

Tasting night with some buddies:  Sweet corn. caramel and vanilla on the nose, the same on the medium length finish. Not that anything is different than any other bourbon, just superb in in its execution!
Amazing stuff! It is sweet, vanilla, and tastes like desert bourbon. A must have for a bourbon connoisseur!

This is about as standard as you can get for bourbon.  From the famous mashbill #2 line from Buffalo Trace, this is the least impressive.  Does not even compare to Rock Hill Farms.

The nose is typical, vanilla notes and maple.  Palate continues with these notes and finishes lightly with some tobacco and oak.  Finish lasts about 2 seconds and it's gone.  Just not very complex at all.
Best bourbon I have ever had
Honey on the nose. Citrus and peach finish. Very smooth and easy drinking.
Smooth. Floral butterscotch aroma. Easy to drink. Super enjoyable. Drank it neat - not hot at all.
Always special. Finishing the first bottle I ever had of this.
Wow! Just Wow! One of the best I've had. Incredibly smooth and amazing.
Thanks to Lenny for this one too! @Zslug for the first time :)

Ok I know there are lots of words to describe all aspects of a bourbon tasting...

The best word for ETL - fantastic

12/28/19

Nose: sweet vanilla with hints of apple

Palate: baking and rye spice with sweetness and surprising heat for lower proof

Finish: LONG with cinnamon and rye without being too much. 

Tastes higher proof than it is. If found it for a reasonable price, grab it!
Still my favorite bourbon. Idk why it just sits right with me
Great smooth bourbon. Everything that a bourbon should have is in this.
Caramel nose and a really spicy finish which seems to last forever. Really good bourbon.

Found a bottle and after trying it 3 times, I'm not a fan. It's not a bad bourbon, but it's not worth the price and highly overrated. Very light, a bit peppery, and short finish. Not much complexity. I'll leave Elmer to others.
Very smooth. Not a lot of burn.
Tasty but a little harsh on the backend. Nice and full flavor
Still at the whiskey bar with the crew. This is fantastic. Glad to get a hold of it

Happened to luck upon this bottle one evening on a Blanton hunt.  Obviously this ran me more, but was a great score.  

Starts with a candied citrus nose that begs you to take a sip.

Very smooth taste of honey and vanilla with sinter brown sugar thrown in. This gives way to a smooth cinnamon and nutmeg finish. Trying not too like this too much due to its scarcity, but not succeeding.  This is really nice stuff.
I've been blessed with many things in this life... an arm like a damn rocket, a cock like a Burmese python, and ETL.
Malty aroma; smooth butterscotch with a nice back-end warmth. I did not detect as much spiciness as reputed.
Cinnamon apple pie on the nose and the taste aligns nicely. Highly recommend this one.

After searching for about 6 months I finally found a bottle. I hesitated to open it because I wanted to enjoy it on a special occasion. I decided to take it to thanksgiving dinner where I shared a glass with a fellow whiskey lover. Easily the best bourbon I have ever tasted, however I have yet to try Pappy.

Elmer T. Lee is a single barrel sour mash Kentucky Straight Bourbon bottled at 45% ABV. It is so incredibly warm, welcoming, and smooth.

Color: Golden Amber 

Nose: Caramel, maple, vanilla, brown sugar, oak, honey, leather and toffee.

Palate: Caramel, vanilla, honey, oak, and cinnamon spice arise.

Finish: Medium to long in length, dry, with hints of cinnamon spice and oak.
Spice. Sweet. Vanilla. Caramel. A little hot. Powerful. Coats the mouth. Citrus. Very, very good. Superb whiskey.

Nose- maple syrup, vanilla, apple pie sprinkled with cinnamon , caramel

Palate- apple pie, cinnamon, baking spices, vanilla ice cream

Finish- Long, chewy and drying finish with notes of toasted oak and caramel apples

Great bourbon. Like a fresh apple pie dusted with cinnamon. Great finish. Very balanced and could drink this every day. Fantastic all around and would pour this for anyone just getting into bourbon. Amazing for MSRP, secondary is meh. This would be my daily drinker by a mile if I could consistently find it.
Vanilla and caramel aroma and flavor with some cinnamon on the finish. Lighter body and flavor.
Pairs so well with Breaking Bad.
Nose:  Vanilla and apple pie.  A little spice up front and then a nice medium-short finish.  Would like it to be a bit stronger, but all in all very hard to beat.

Yeah I agree with the average score given. Not super complex or rich in flavor but it is flawless  in execution of what it is. I get Apple Jacks and Vanilla wafers on the nose. It’s warm and very inviting. Palate is baked apples with heaps of cinnamon over the top. Finish is a little peach cobbler, apple crisp and a brief touch of cedar. It’s very enjoyable and agreeable with most palates I suspect.
Nice, but maybe I was too excited.  Very smooth and enjoyable to drink though.
Spice +++. Cinnamon, oak, caramel on the palate. Cinnamon and vanilla medium finish. One of my favorites.
Sweet and spicy nose, flavor is smooth like chocolate, almost citrusy spice
Last birthday pour. Gotta have all my favorites, no?
Really good but way over hyped in my book.
Slightly spicy nose followed by Carmel and vanilla. Smooth and sweet taste, with a slightly spicy finish that lingers.

Vanilla/oak nose. A spicy front, with a full brown sugar, honey, and vanilla profile. Full/oak in the middle, and a perfect Tennessee hug to finish. One of the best I’ve had. It’s got everything you’d want in a bourbon.

Delicate nose of maraschino cherries orange zest and lemon rind. Oak is mush more present on the palate with vanilla clove and nutmeg layering over the fruit. Everything comes together nicely in the finish and creates a very cohesive drink
Unreal. Cinnamon, petrol, viscous fruit, orange peel, cardamom, and caramel. One of the best ive had.
Really tasty and smooth. If you can find it buy it.

Carmel and light nose. Gives way to light cherry over time. Definitely close to Eagle a Rare. 

Very light palate. Short finish. Pleasant but lacking. 

I use the rating scale below. Distiller uses a scale of 5 and I use a scale of 10, but I’m sure you’re not too drunk to do the math! 

1. Disgusting - So bad I poured it out.
2. Poor - I wouldn't consume by choice.
3. Bad - Multiple flaws.
4. Below average - Not bad, but many things I'd rather have.
5. Good - Just average.
6. Very Good - Better than average.
7. Great - Well above average.
8. Excellent - In a league of its own.
9. Incredible - An all-time favorite.
10. Perfect
Definitely one of the best bourbons!  I Added ice during a hot day and it was actually better...  worth it if you can find it!
Very, very smooth. No bite at all. Highly recommend.
Sampled at a buddies. Another nice pour.
